instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: Solution to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro GPU/freezing problem
threads.message:
So I've got 2 of these <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> machines that do the exact same thing. both of them run great until you try to play a video in full screen, then they shut down. When booted back up i get the error report that says GPU Panic error. i ran ASD EFI and it passed. When i run ASD O.S. it fails for IC0R.

almost seems like another issue like in the 2010 15" machines with the shit capacitor.

has anyone known this to be a common issue with this board?

threads.title: Solution to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro GPU/freezing problem
threads.message: Yeah, a common issue covered by an Apple replacement program. Plug them into a good casing assembly and get them replaced for free. GPU failure.

threads.title: Solution to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro GPU/freezing problem
threads.message:
Resolder <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>, don't pull them pre heat the board and drag your iron around the pins with some fresh solder.

The Apple program ended 2 months ago........

threads.title: Solution to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro GPU/freezing problem
threads.message: A large majority of the 3332 boards are still covered (4 years from original date of purchase). I've had 2 repaired in the past month. They will have the original date of purchase on file, but you're right, a lot of them will not be covered any longer.

threads.title: Solution to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro GPU/freezing problem
threads.message: Resoldering <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> is a quicker way for me. It really is the only issue with these boards, GPU has nothing wrong with it.

threads.title: Solution to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro GPU/freezing problem
threads.message: That's good to know, and a great help. Thanks, duke--as always!

threads.title: Solution to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro GPU/freezing problem
threads.message: You found it here, world first. Not seen anyone figured out <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> yet. Done 3 this week so far, another gold mine like 2850 boards.

threads.title: Solution to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro GPU/freezing problem
threads.message: That's good to know; I can save time sending people to Apple to check on their coverage, and then having them come back for OOW repair. Thanks, duke.

threads.title: Solution to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro GPU/freezing problem
threads.message: It's just better in any case to just fix the original board. The refurb garbage boards that Apple is using you never know what you going to get.
